pageContext.claim: “I'm also proud that here in Pennsylvania, your Medicare Advantage. You know that everybody have it, some people have it. The premiums have decreased. Listen to this, under our management, 43% since I took office.”
pageContext.analysis: Our colleagues at FactCheck.org produced a good dissection of Trump's misleading claims concerning Medicare premiums. Medicare Advantage average national premiums have gone down under Trump's administration, and they went up under Obama — by less than 50 cents. (Also, there isn't one Medicare premium; what people pay depends on their plan choices. In fact, 60% of Medicare Advantage enrollees pay no premium for their plan. But among those who do pay a premium, the amounts are noticeably higher than the nationwide average for all plans.) Moreover, the larger expense that affects most enrollees is the Part B premium, which has gone up under both administrations. In fact, Part B premiums have gone up faster in Trump’s first three years than they did in Obama’s first three years.
